nodes.bodyText: Add the service update exception details in the result as well?
Tried to add original SUE as suppressed but it won't get reported in deployment result, so replace the result with SUE and only log IOE here
RollbackCompletes() delete the old  "broken" directory. I guess we want to keep the last broken dir
If broken dir exists, it indicates stage rollback. If we want to keep the last broken, we can add back the previous-X pointers in the launch dir

If rollback fails and we call rollbackComplete() , then the broken dir is the failed deployment dir, and current dir is the deployment before that (which was once successful). I'm ok with this for now. We can discuss offline
I'm wondering if we should swallow the exception here. Maybe it's better to handle in the rollback failure
Makes sense. I'll think over it.

We don't have a way to handle it actually. I can maybe return unable-to-rollback directory here.
EDIT: let's discuss offline
maybe Use Jackson?
Right. Will undo this change.
NIT: I feel it a little weird to pass bootstrapManager and deploymentDirManager as parameter here. These can be private fields of KernelAlts and set from either context or KernelCommandline
Yeah I did that initially. But those two fields are only used once here in this method.
make this default value in logger?
curious why use this?
No specific reason actually. I just need a timestamp before this kernel start
throw the exception instead?
NIT: this line can be moved to call() so that you don't need to break the @AllArgsConstructor :P
True. I can change it back.

This can be tricky because tempRootDir and e2eTestPkgStoreDir might be the same directory. It was causing problem before when prepare local deployment store and copy file recursively from one folder to another (I see you removed that copy file logic). I'll still prefer e2eTestPkgStoreDir = tempRootDir.resolve("eteTestPkgStore");
The problem is tempRootDir was shared by all e2e tests. I'm not sure if that's ok. and e2eTestPkgStoreDir needs to be static based on our upload logic
Is 100 coming from our design terminology?
Yes. The reserved ones are 100 and 101
Anyone new reading the code will not understand. May either remove it or explain.

Do we need shutdown in case when bootstrap did not happen correctly? The directories have been adjusted I believe as part of kernelAlts.prepareRollback(). Can't we push the deployment with rollback stage in the queue at this point?
Correct, we reverted the launch dir changes with kernelAlts.prepareRollback. but this kernel is launched from the broken new launch dir, so we have to restart from old launch dir again.
Does bootstrap tasks follow dependency order? If not can we restart only once after all tasks have finished?

Yes. it's ordered by dependency.
It can be an option, but we won't get details of which bootstrap leads to failure
ok. If its dependency ordered then current implementation is probably better approach.

Name seems to indicate that it will execute all the tasks and then return but it executes one by one and returns after executing one. Probably rename it to indicate this behavior, that would also make the if check in next line more intuitive.
If not restart/reboot request, it does move on to the next bootstrap task. And it returns right away for restart/reboot
ya thats right. Ok I think the naming is fine then
Where is the IOException coming from and does that need to be handled separately?
IOException can happen when saving bootstrap status to file. I cannot think of a better way to recover from IOException
